doc/source/developer_resources/stx_ipv6_.message: "In StarlingX releases before release 2.0, which has all required packages in the ISO image,"
Beginning in the StarlingX 2.0 release a native bare metal..."
"with OpenStack running within containers on top of the..."

The IP address depends on the resolver configured for the container. In our case, it is the embedded dns resolver. Here is a description about that "Docker (aka Moby) internally uses libnetwork to configure and enable the embedded DNS resolver. Libnetwork binds the resolver to the container's loopback interface, so that DNS queries at 127.0.0.11 can be routed (via iptables) to the "backend DNS resolver" in the Docker Engine."

pkg/remote/redfish/utils.go.message:
the default case appears to be a positive result, but unless I'm missing something it's being returned as an error on line 160.

Shouldn't it come back as nil if unmarshal is successful from block on 142?
Thanks for clarifying, I misunderstood the code on my first pass.

> the default case appears to be a positive result, but unless I'm
 > missing something it's being returned as an error on line 160.


The default case is a negative result. The HTTP status code is the most reliable indicator of success, and according to spec, it can only be 200 or 204; those cases are on L114 and L116.

Any suggestions to make this clearer?


 > Shouldn't it come back as nil if unmarshal is successful from block
 > on 142?


The only reason I can think of to unmarshal the redfish response is when there is an error. Since the unmarshaling can only happen if the HTTP status isn't 200 or 204, we have to be throwing an error down there regardless of the marshaling result. If we were marshaling on 200 and 204 responses, I would agree.

We also need to make sure that we are setting below reserved_stores under glance-api.conf

[os_glance_staging_store]

TripleO is configuring the following directories for this function:

  /var/lib/glance/os_glance_staging_store
  /var/lib/glance/os_glance_tasks_store

I have confirmed it works as I have done an image import and saw temporary content there until the copy is complete and then it's deleted from the above when the image is in the DCN Ceph cluster.

So this is working though it's not using the /opt/stack directories, which actually don't exist when TripleO uses puppet-glance to deploy containerized glance. The configuration is generated by puppet and put into the following on the container host:

 /var/lib/config-data/puppet-generated/glance_api/etc/glance

and the glance container is then started with something like this:

podman run \
...
-v /var/log/containers/glance:/var/log/glance:z \
-v /var/lib/kolla/config_files/glance_api.json:/var/lib/kolla/config_files/config.json \
-v /var/lib/config-data/puppet-generated/glance_api/:/var/lib/kolla/config_files/src:ro \
...

[root@dcn0-distributedcomputehci-0 glance]# podman exec -ti glance_api /bin/bash

os_glance_staging_store:
.  ..

os_glance_tasks_store:
.  ..
()[glance@dcn0-distributedcomputehci-0 /var/lib/glance]$

total 0
drwxr-xr-x. 2 root root  6 May 11  2019 .
drwxr-xr-x. 1 root root 47 Apr 17 20:35 ..
()[glance@dcn0-distributedcomputehci-0 /]$

specs/ussuri/approved/nova-cyborg-intera.message:
Not sure I understand this. The TEST_PCI attach handles should only be produced when the fake driver is "enabled", which it should never be in a production environment. And in a test environment, the whole point of enabling the fake driver would be so that nova (or other cyborg consumers) can treat the fake attach handles like they would any other.

Am I missing something?

> and composed them in the domain XML, the VM will not come up --
 > libvirt/qemu will fail it.

So the idea is that, by ignoring these attach handles, the VM *will* come up, just without (these) devices?

I'm not sure how that's better.

At least if the BDFs were in the XML, you could potentially verify they ended up in there. If they're not, what good does it do that the VM came up?

...Because presumably we're only doing this in a tempest test that sets up a device profile from nova in the first place, which we should only be doing when we're testing nova's use of cyborg. So it's not like these failed VMs will be a problem for other tests.

What I'm getting at is, we really ought to avoid having test-only logic in production code. IIUC what this is proposing is to inject something like:

 if handle['type'] != 'TEST_PCI':
     add_pci_dom_xml()

...into the virt driver's spawn flow. And that should be avoided unless it's truly unavoidable.

> if ... arqs[0]['attach_handle_type'] == 'PCI':

Okay, this makes me feel better. I'm convinced, thanks for patiently explaining.

> At least if the BDFs were in the XML, you could potentially verify they ended up in there. 

How? There is no VM or xml after libvirt/qemu crashes and burns. If you are proposing to scrape the n-cpu logs, that's a sketchy idea. 

And how do you know why the VM bringup failed? It could be because libvirt/qemu failed it, or something else went wrong in some code path, which is a real test failure. Short of log-scraping, I don't see how we'll determine that.

> If they're not, what good does it do that the VM came up?

If the VM did spawn successfully, at least we know the code flow is good till the point where PCI devices need to be injected into the VM's XML. That includes the logic in the Nova API server, conductor, scheduler, compute manager and the parts of the virt driver till creation of guest config. It exercises all Cyborg APIs that are involved in VM creation: get device profile request groups, create/bind ARQs, wait for Cyborg's notification and query Cyborg to get the ARQs.

> ...Because presumably we're only doing this in a tempest test that
> sets up a device profile from nova in the first place, which we
> should only be doing when we're testing nova's use of cyborg. So
> it's not like these failed VMs will be a problem for other tests.

That is a bit beside the point because VM spawn failure is no good for testing the right code flow either.

> What I'm getting at is, we really ought to avoid having test-only logic in production code. 

We are not doing that.

> IIUC what this is proposing is to inject something like:

> if handle['type'] != 'TEST_PCI':
> add_pci_dom_xml()

Referencing the code [1] again:

  if ... arqs[0]['attach_handle_type'] == 'PCI':

This is validating the right attach handle type for production code, not checking whether this is a test case.

We plan to use the same tempest plugin in third-party CI, where Cyborg will return real BDFs. With no change in 'production code', that will:
A. exercise the same code paths, but 
B. can do additional validation like inspecting the xml, and
C. can do additional test cases like programming.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/gitweb?p=openstack/nova.git;f=nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py;hb=refs/changes/45/631245/36#l5738

> The TEST_PCI attach handles should only
 > be produced when the fake driver is "enabled", which it should
 > never be in a production environment. 

Yes.

 > And in a test environment,
 > the whole point of enabling the fake driver would be so that nova
 > (or other cyborg consumers) can treat the fake attach handles like
 > they would any other.

The fake driver returns BDFs which, by definition, don't correspond to real devices. If the virt driver 'treated them like any other,' and composed them in the domain XML, the VM will not come up -- libvirt/qemu will fail it. So, the tempest env can test the code flow from the start all the way through to that point where the virt driver checks the bound ARQs for attach handle type [1]. IOW, all code except that which produces VM's domain XML and creates the instance via libvirt, which is not Cyborg-specific.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/gitweb?p=openstack/nova.git;f=nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py;hb=refs/changes/45/631245/36#l5738

nit: pci ids is a little nebulous 
it could refer to the pci adresses or it could refer to the vendor and product ids.

In Nova, both are accepted (PCI addresses vs. vendor/product IDs tuple)
Honestly, I personnally don't care what Cyborg will ask for configuring the PCI devices, I just want to tell that maybe Cyborg should do the same than Nova if operators have to configure both services.

i guess i dont care enough to argure that pci id is wrogn so ok.

i also agree that cyborg will need a way to filter deivce in the future. the enable or disable driver approach is too course grained in the long run.

True. The statement is true for both interpretations. However, I think the vendor/product ID is most relevant to the operator, because s/he will know them _before_ installing the accelerator card, thus avoiding conflicts proactively.

The operator enables specific drivers in cyborg.conf, like this:

 [agent]
 enabled_drivers = fake_driver

The docs will say what PCI vendor/product IDs are claimed by each driver. So, the operator can decide whether there is a conflict before he installs the cards or enables the driver.

We are investigating APIs to enable or disable a specific device or a set of devices, possibly based on PCI vendor/device IDs, BDFs, host IDs/names or some combination. This is WIP for Ussuri. That would be along the lines of what you are saying.

IIUC:

In cyborg, you cast a net around a bunch of devices by enabling a driver that knows how to deal with those devices. In Ussuri, that will be "all or nothing" -- either the driver is enabled and covers all those devices, or the driver is disabled and covers none of them.

In nova, PCI whitelisting.

And the point is, the deployer needs to make sure those sets don't overlap.

In the future, there may be a mechanism whereby you could refine the cyborg set more granularly; but that's an exercise for later. (Actually the vision is to use unified provider config YAML that both nova and cyborg would read to find out who gets to own a particular device. Die [pci]passthrough_whitelist, die.)

(BTW, I'm good with the nebulousness of "PCI ID". It saves us having to go into specifics of vendor/product/bdf/etc which are not salient here.)

neutron/db/db_base_plugin_v2.py.message:
I don't understand why we need 3 methods: delete_subnet(), _delete_subnet_commit() and _delete_subnet().
In fact those 2 lines are exactly the same as _delete_subnet() method. Do we need this _delete_subnet method?

I understand your concerns with this.

- delete_subnet is the API entry function when a subnet is deleted. This one calls _delete_subnet_commit.
- _delete_subnet_commit deletes the DB register, emits the precommit message and the IPAM registers
- _delete_subnet is called from delete_network only. That will delete the DB register and will notify the after_delete event. I can't add this event to _delete_subnet_commit because I need to send the event outside the write context.

Instead of having those three methods, I can remove "_delete_subnet" and call those two commands from delete_network

neutron/db/models_v2.py.message: Do you think it would be a helpful signpost for a future developer to mention that this is only in use for deletion operations at the moment, which is why no unlock_register exists - the lock is deleted not unlocked.  This makes it different from a standard mutex.  I can imagine someone looking at this class without the context of the rest of this change puzzling about why there is no unlock concept.

I'll add this info in the class description. I (we) want to be sure this mixin is used correctly.

This is not only used during the deletion operation but when IPAM is reading subnets and calculating the IPs from those subnets.

The lock lifespan is just the DB transaction where is called. Once the transaction finishes, this "lock" ends.

Yes, I still have to get that figured out.

exit_event.wait()

ovn_octavia_provider/driver.py.message: Wondering if I should have removed start()...
Its a helper for handling this caching in attributes. I think we can get rid of that now.
This should be moved to driver agent.
We should move it to the driver agent.

OvnProviderHelper uses:    

self.helper_thread = threading.Thread(target=self.request_handler)
self.helper_thread.daemon = True

I think that with initializing the OvnProviderHelper by OvnProviderDriver per each API call we should take care of properly closing the helper_thread.
Isn't that done in the shutdown() method on L276?

I think we have a thread leak here.

Example:
After creating LB, like:
openstack loadbalancer create --provider ovn --vip-subnet-id a973d603-4b76-4124-844f-d41fb584e5fe --name test

After each request the octavia-wsgi thread numbers is increasing:
ps -eLf | grep octavia-uwsgi | wc -l

Hey!

the octavia-api wsgi process creates OVNProviderDriver, that has OvnProviderHelper. OvnProviderHelper creates a queue thread and IDLs.

While API  call ends the object of OVNProviderDriver is destroyed, but related OvnProviderHelper and queue are still untouched.

I tried to tweak a bit the __delete__ method OvnProviderHelper and destroy related OVNProviderHelper, clients and queue in it, but without any affect for now...

Thanks, I'm still looking into it.

This was missing. The connection in:
from ovsdbapp.backend.ovs_idl import connection

Is also cached. Without stopping it here after each API call we had 2 additional threads not closed. Now it is working properly:


stack@devstack:~/$
echo $(ps -eLf | grep octavia-uwsgi | wc -l); echo $(netstat -natp | grep 6641 | grep ESTA| grep uwsgi | wc -l)
6
0

echo $(ps -eLf | grep octavia-uwsgi | wc -l); echo $(netstat -natp | grep 6641 | grep ESTA| grep uwsgi | wc -l)
6

ovn_octavia_provider/event.py.message:
I checked that now after moving this event to driver agent, sometimes the Load_Balancer row is not yet created in the DB by the driver, but in meantime we received, that LB_VIP_PORT has been created (by driver). Its typical race condition.

Now, while driver still works on creating the LB row, we try to perform:

self.driver.vip_port_update_handler(row)

but it needs LB row to be created first - the self._find_ovn_lbs() in vip_port_update_handler cannot find the load_balancer and it fails.

This is only one place where we need LB row first while performing actions on event. We could just retry here.

.zuul.yaml.message: Maybe it works in both ways, but why don't use 'lioadm' ? I took as an example the "cinder-tempest-plugin-lvm-tgt" job.

"devstack_localrc": {
"ADMIN_PASSWORD": "secretadmin",
"CINDER_ISCSI_HELPER": "lioadm",
...

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/58/537658/3/check/cinder-tempest-plugin-lvm-lio/b3264ce/job-output.json.gz
this doesn't seem needed as tgtadm is already the default target

Maybe a common base job could be created from the common part of the lvm-lio-barbican job and this one, and both could inherit from it. In fact they are mostly the same.

You also need

    roles:
      - zuul: opendev.org/openstack/cinderlib

See cinder-temepest-plugin-lvm-lio-barbican's definition.

In another review we are trying to get rid of this; maybe it's really time to switch to the tempest one:
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/717379/7/.zuul.yaml

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
You are mixing things.

'i440fx' is PCI machine and ignores num_pcie_ports completely as this is setting for PCIe machines like 'aarch64/virt' or 'x86/q35'.
if you set 0 then you mean 'I trust libvirt to add whatever is needed' which usually means enough slots for whatever is in XML given to libvirt + 1-2 free slots.

And break AArch64.

When I added 'num_pcie_ports' variable I did checks on 'x86/q35 +bios', 'x86/q35+uefi' and 'aarch64/virt' systems. 28 was what was bootable on AArch64 at that time.

nova/conf/libvirt.py.message:
This 32 is wrong for AArch64.  Based on today's investigation the default number of ports for different architectures.

From this morning's testing on real AArch64 hardware (thanks to libvirt developer, Andrea Bolognani):

* With 32 root ports: it doesn't boot all the way through -- it just hangs before GRUB and never ends up in the shell
* With the magic number 28 root ports: doesn't boot
* With 24 root ports: the guest booted all the way through

I will update here, once the dust settles, as the QEMU / libvirt folks are still testing.

doc/source/reference/job_def.rst.message: I had similar concerns, but after raising them with Albin in IRC yesterday I realized that the sentences leading up to this still make it clear. "A hard dependency will cause an error if the specified job is not run. [...] A soft dependency will not cause Zuul to report an error [under this same condition]."
The soft dependency is not about reporting an error but about still running the job even if the dependent job is not in the buildset. So I think this change simplifies this a little bit too much.
